Stem: People who have an MBA degree earn significantly higher salaries, on average, than those who do not. Give one reason why this might be true, other than the degree (or the education) causing the higher salary.

Aliases: already on fast track at work

RunsThroughA.text: The MBA teaches valuable business skills and management techniques that employers pay more for.
RunsThroughA.explanation: This is A->B (Human Capital Theory). The skills learned during the MBA (A) cause the higher salary (B).

RunsThroughA.text: The MBA degree acts as a signal of competence to employers, so they are willing to pay them more.
RunsThroughA.explanation: This is A->B (Signaling Theory). The degree itself causes the higher pay because of how employers interpret the credential.

RunsThroughA.text: You gain access to the business school's alumni network during the program, which helps you get better jobs.
RunsThroughA.explanation: This is A->Mediator->B. The network gained during the MBA (Mediator) is a direct consequence of pursuing the degree (A). This must be distinguished from pre-existing networks.

RunsThroughA.text: The MBA credential itself qualifies them for high-paying management roles that others can't get.
RunsThroughA.explanation: This is A->B (Credentialism). The degree causes the higher salary by acting as a prerequisite.

RunsThroughA.text: The MBA gives people the confidence to ask for higher salaries.
RunsThroughA.explanation: This is A->Mediator->B. The confidence (Mediator) is caused by the degree (A).

Good.text: People who are highly ambitious are more likely to pursue an MBA and also more likely to work harder and negotiate higher salaries.
Good.explanation: This correctly identifies a common cause (ambition).

Good.text: Individuals from wealthy backgrounds can afford the tuition for an MBA and also have family connections that lead to better jobs.
Good.explanation: This correctly identifies a common cause related to SES and networks.
